title: Detecting Good Arguments in a Non-Topic-Specific Way: An Oxymoron?
authors:
Beigman Klebanov, Beata  and
Gyawali, Binod  and
Song, Yi
venue: Proceedings of the 55th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (Volume 2: Short Papers)
abstract: Automatic identification of good arguments on a controversial topic has applications in civics and education, to name a few. While in the civics context it might be acceptable to create separate models for each topic, in the context of scoring of studentsâ€™ writing there is a preference for a single model that applies to all responses. Given that good arguments for one topic are likely to be irrelevant for another, is a single model for detecting good arguments a contradiction in terms? We investigate the extent to which it is possible to close the performance gap between topic-specific and across-topics models for identification of good arguments.
